children.name: when sth can be done or achieved
possible
children.definition: if something is possible, it can be done or achievedOPP impossible:
examples: Is it possible toget tickets for the game?
It might be possible forthe documentstobe sent over.
as soon/quickly/much etc as possibleas soon, quickly etc as you can :
I need the money as soon as possible.
Sharon always does as little work as possible.
The original features of the house have been preservedas far as possible(= as much as possible)
possibly[adv] B2
It was the best vacation you could possibly imagine.

children.name: it is possible to do something
examples: From the hilltop it was possible to see the sea.

children.name: make it possible to do something
examples: Medical advances have made it possible to keep more patients alive.

children.name: if possible
children.definition: alsoif at all possible
examples: If possible, take light exercise first thing in the morning.

children.name: where/wherever/whenever possible
examples: Choose wholemeal varieties of flour and pasta, where possible.

children.name: do/try everything possible
examples: We must do everything possible to limit our impact on the earth's environment.

children.name: in every way possible
examples: The company helped promote the scheme in every way possible.

children.name: perfectly/quite possible
children.definition: definitely possible
examples: Combining a family with a career is perfectly possible .

children.name: theoretically possible
children.definition: possible in theory, but difficult and unlikely
examples: It is theoretically possible for all students to get full marks.

children.name: technically possible
children.definition: possible with the technology available
examples: Amendments to software may be technically possible, but are inadvisable.

children.name: humanly possible
children.definition: possible for anyone
examples: It is not humanly possible to work for more than fifteen hours a day.

children.name: can be done
children.definition: if something can be done, it is possible to do it: có thể được hoàn tất
examples: ▪ The job can be done by Friday if we all make an effort.
▪ I’m sure that more could be done to help the homeless.
▪ Val got her MA while she was working full-time, so it can be done.

children.name: feasible
children.definition: a plan, idea, or method that is feasible is possible and is likely to work: khả thi
examples: ▪ Barrington suggest transporting the supplies by air. This of course is perfectly feasible.
▪ We agreed on a feasible plan and within a week we implemented it.
feasibility[U] whether something is feasible: tính khả thi
▪ Experts are studying the feasibility of a solar energy project.

children.name: it is feasible to do sth
examples: ▪ It is not feasible to have security cameras in every part of the building.

children.name: it is feasible that
examples: ▪ Da Silva considered it feasible that uranium could be produced on an industrial scale.

children.name: economically/technically/politically etc feasible
examples: It was no longer financially feasible to keep the community centre open.

children.name: workable
children.definition: a workable way of doing sth is a possible way of doing it - use this when you have had a lot of problems finding a suitable way: “hoạt động”, hiệu quả, khả thi
examples: There is a dispute over land but we believe we have found a workable solution to this problem.
A new plan provides for loans to students, but to make the system workable more government funding will be needed.

children.name: doable
children.definition: informalif sth is doable, you have enough money, energy, or skill to do it : có thể thực hiện được
examples: This exercise programme is doable for most people.
Do you think the walk is doable?
Hosting great parties is fun, easy, and doable on any budget.
The book is full of interesting and doable recipes.

children.name: attainable
children.definition: formalan aim or standard that is attainable is one that can be achieved and it is reasonable to try to achieve it: có thể đạt được
examples: Every child should be educated to the highest attainable level.
Perfect democracy is not attainable, nor is perfect freedom or perfect justice.

children.name: viable
children.definition: a viable way of doing something is one that is possible and should work well: có thể thực hiện được, khả thi
examples: ▪ Do you think this is a viable proposition?
▪ Nuclear energy is the only viable alternative to coal or gas.
▪ They are in favour of the program, but they want strong assurances that it is viable.

children.name: achievable
children.definition: describes a task, etc. that is possible to achieve
examples: Before you set your targets, make sure that they are achievable.
A 15% cut in carbon emissions is achievable.

children.name: unattainable
children.definition: /ˌʌnəˈteɪnəbəl/  impossible to achieve:
examples: ▪ Television can create deep dissatisfaction by portraying lifestyles that are unattainable.
▪ The new exams have been designed for weaker students who, until now, have been set unattainable targets.
▪ For many young people in rural areas, a university education seems like an unattainable dream.

children.name: out of reach
children.definition: /ˌaʊt əv ˈriːtʃ/  impossible to get or achieve - use this about your aims and things you want very much:
examples: ▪ A cure for the HIV virus may not be out of reach for much longer.
▪ Peace in the region remained the goal, but a permanent solution still seemed out of reach.

children.name: possibility
children.definition: an opportunity to do something, or something that can be done or tried : khả năng (có thể thực hiện)
examples: possibilities for/of (doing) something
exciting possibilities for reducing costs
We are considering the possibility of providing a new class for advanced students.

children.name: consider a possibility
children.definition: think about whether you should take an opportunity
examples: We even began to consider the possibility of moving there permanently.

children.name: explore a possibility
children.definition: think carefully and find out about an opportunity
examples: You may want to explore the possibility of setting up your own business.

children.name: offer a possibility
children.definition: make an opportunity available
examples: Technology offers exciting possibilities to designers.

children.name: open up a possibility
children.definition: make a new opportunity available
examples: His recent performance opens up the possibility for him to compete in the Olympic Games.

children.name: exhaust the possibilities
children.definition: try everything possible
examples: I was determined not to give up until I had exhausted all the possibilities.

children.name: new possibilities
examples: New possibilities lay before him.

children.name: exciting possibilities
examples: The city offers many exciting possibilities for young people.

children.name: tremendous possibilities
children.definition: very good or important opportunities
examples: This discovery opens up tremendous possibilities for cancer screening.

children.name: reach
children.definition: nounLIMIT
examples: [ S or U ] the limit within which someone can achieve something
_An expensive trip like that would be completelybeyond/out of(my) reach (= I
would not have enough money to pay for it) .
_After years of saving, the car was at lastwithin(her) reach (= she had enough money to pay for it) .

children.name: impossibility
children.definition: sth that is impossible to do:
examples: At first they thought that building a bridge across to the island was an impossibility.
The equal division of all roles is a practical impossibility for many parents.
I was suddenly struck by the impossibility of achieving our aims.
One hundred percent airline security is a practical impossibility.

children.name: unsustainable
children.definition: adjective

children.name: Something that is unsustainable cannot continue at the same rate
examples: _The level of spending on pensions is unsustainable.

children.name: when sth can't be done or achieved
out of the question
children.definition: if an idea or suggestion is out of the question, it is completely impossible or it cannot be allowed: hoàn toàn không thể
examples: ▪ I’d love to come with you, but with all the work I have to do it’s out of the question.
▪ The cost would be over $5000, which is quite out of the question.

children.name: it’s out of the question for somebody (to do something)
examples: ▪ I’m afraid it’s out of the question for you to go alone.

children.name: there's no way
children.definition: there’s no way/ðeəʳz ˌnəʊ ˈweɪ/ especially spoken say this when you strongly believe that something is impossible: chẳng có cách nào

children.name: there’s no way (that)
examples: ▪ There’s no way we can get to the airport in less than an hour.

children.name: there’s no way of knowing something
examples: ▪ There’s no way of knowing when the volcano will erupt again.

children.name: can't possibly U
children.definition: can’t possibly especially spoken use this in order to emphasize that you think sth is impossible:
examples: You know we can’t possibly pay as much as that in rent.
That was delicious but I couldn’t possibly eat another thing!

children.name: impossible
children.definition: sth that is impossible cannot be done:
examples: We’re supposed to do all this work by tomorrow, but it’s impossible.
It’s a seemingly impossible task.
not possible[adj] impossible or extremely difficult to do:
We can’t buy a new computer for every student - it’s just not possible.
it is not possible (for sb/sth) to do sth
It is not possible, in a book of this size, to cover every aspect of the subject.
She’s in a meeting, so I’m afraid it’s not possible for you to see her now.

children.name: seem impossible
examples: It seemed impossible that he would ever recover from the injury.

children.name: become impossible
examples: As it became darker, it became impossible for the players to see the ball.

children.name: prove impossible
children.definition: be impossible because you have tried but not succeeded
examples: It proved impossible for the two sides to reach an agreement.

children.name: find something impossible
examples: He found it impossible to sleep because of the noise coming from next door.

children.name: make something impossible
examples: Heavy snow made travelling impossible.

children.name: render something impossibleformal
children.definition: make something impossible
examples: The large number of prison guards rendered any escape impossible.

children.name: absolutely impossible
children.definition: alsoutterly impossibleformal
examples: It is absolutely impossible to drive in these conditions.

children.name: almost/nearly impossible
examples: He thought that winning would be almost impossible.

children.name: virtually/practically impossible
children.definition: almost impossible
examples: Getting tickets for the concert is practically impossible.

children.name: well-nigh impossibleformal
children.definition: almost impossible
examples: Policing the entire coastline is well-nigh impossible.

children.name: seemingly impossible
children.definition: seeming to be impossible
examples: He managed to win the chess game from a seemingly impossible position.

children.name: physically impossible
examples: It is physically impossible to survive for long in the desert without water.

children.name: an impossible job/task
examples: He faced the impossible task of paying back huge debts.

children.name: an impossible feat
children.definition: something that is impossible to do
examples: She achieved the seemingly impossible feat of breaking the world record.

children.name: an impossible dream
children.definition: something you want, but will never happen
examples: For a small club, winning the cup final will always be the impossible dream.

children.name: impossible demands
examples: She was growing tired of the company’s impossible demands.

children.name: it is impossible to do sth
examples: It is impossible to know if this story is true.

children.name: difficult, if not impossible
children.definition: difficult, and perhaps impossible
examples: Obtaining funding for the film will be difficult, if not impossible.

children.name: it is impossible (for sb/sth) to do sth
examples: The twins are so alike that it’s impossible to tell them apart.
The street was narrow and it was impossible for the two buses to pass.

children.name: impractical
children.definition: an idea, suggestion, or action that is impractical is not really possible because it would cost far too much money, waste too much time, be much too difficult etc: không thực tế
examples: Officials stated that building a dam for irrigation purposes was hopelessly impractical.
Telling people to avoid any exposure to the sun is impractical advice.

children.name: it is impractical to do something
examples: It would be impractical to attempt to review all the types of multimedia technology in thisstudy.

children.name: hopeless
children.definition: if sth that you try to do is hopeless, there is no possibility of it being successful:
examples: ▪ Police now face the hopeless task of trying to find the bombers.

children.name: it is hopeless
examples: ▪ ‘Please let me go to the party’ Ali begged her mother, but she knew it was hopeless.

children.name: it is hopeless to do sth
examples: ▪ It’s hopeless to try to persuade him while he’s in this mood. Let’s talk to him tomorrow.

children.name: a hopeless causesomething that cannot possibly succeed
examples: ▪ ‘I do not believe that working to block the movement of cocaine into the US is a hopeless cause,’ McCaffrey told the panel.

children.name: not have a hope U
children.definition: not stand a chance/not have a hope/nɒt ˌstænd ə ˈtʃɑːnsǁ-ˈtʃæns, nɒt ˌhæv ə ˈhəʊp/  informal to not have any chance of doing what you want, for example because it is much too difficult, someone else will do it first etc:
examples: ▪ Everyone in the town votes Republican. The Democrats don’t stand a chance.
▪ There’s no point in me applying for the job. I wouldn’t have a hope.

children.name: not stand a chance of doing something
examples: ▪ ‘The driver of the train didn’t stand a chance of stopping in time,’ a Railtrack spokesman said.

children.name: not have a hope/have no hope of doing something
examples: ▪ The bank said that it will no longer lend to enterprises that have no hope of making a profit.

children.name: can’t be done
children.definition: it spokenused when saying very definitely that something is impossible :
examples: I’m afraid it can’t be done.
